ADDITIONAL CONTEXT?

 This is the GHI that tracked the fix to this: https://github.com/trilogy-group/eng-maintenance/issues/14663 

 They provided the build that was sent to this customer, which didn't work according to them. Logs provided, so I guess next up is to re-open the GHI (I don't understand why the issue is closed without confirmation that the fix works, over and over... was it always this way?) 

 AI: 

LIKELY ROOT CAUSE

 	* A defect in ContentSecurity.NodeProvider.VSNodes.EnumVsRules(...) handling of one engine/rule entry being null or missing a property, causing a NullReference. This may persist despite the “should have worked” build if the environment data triggers an edge case the fix didn’t account for.

WHAT TO DO NEXT

 	* Validate build bits/versions actually deployed for the fix:
 	* Check file version of ContentSecurity.NodeProvider.dll under wwwconf\bin and Attendant\bin against the intended hotfix build.
 	* Quick mitigations:
 	* Recycle the MailEssentials app pool or restart W3SVC (UI only) and retest the “Virus scan engines” page.
 	* Clear ASP.NET temp for the site and recycle app pool.
 	* Collect precise exception details:
 	* Check Windows Application Event Log for w3wp.exe .NET exceptions around 11:31:14 with stack traces for ContentSecurity.NodeProvider.VSNodes.
 	* If still failing:
 	* Share the versions of ContentSecurity.NodeProvider.dll and MEC.ConfigurationServices.* assemblies.
 	* Engineering should harden EnumVsRules against null entries and log which rule ID/name fails; a simple guard will avoid the crash and surface which engine/rule is malformed.

 I reviewed the engine/update logs and peeked into the PDF header; here’s what persists and what doesn’t. 

 	* Yes — I’m basing this on the logs.
 	* Mail flow/scanning works; no signs of “all mail routed to FailedMails”.info   GfiMeSmtpAgent Processing messageinfo   GfiMeSmtpAgent LocalEndPoint: 192.168.50.10:2525
 	* EE exploit engine loads OK; no “Failed to load eecore (126)”.info   EEPlugin Initialization routine found in the eecore, calling...info   EEPlugin Initialization routine found in the eecore, calling...ok[0x0]
 	* SCore shows normal plugin mapping; no “plugin not loaded … aborting scan”.info   SCore CCoreContext::Init: source reg path[...sources\151]info   SCore Mapper: plugins[3;12;4;13;11;6;15;1;2;20]
 	* Avira updater runs (no errors seen in our window); BitDefender is disabled in VSE; Sophos loads.info   autoupdate update server: http://meupdate.gfi.cominfo   autoupdate engine_directory: C:\Program Files (x86)\GFI\MailEssentials\updater\AVIRA...info   autoupdate AuDownload::read_version_info(...)
 	* The standout issue is UI-only: VSNodes nullref when building Virus Scan Engines; VSE also shows Cyren rule-status errors that likely trigger the null.error  vsnodes Error :: System.NullReferenceException ...;   bei ContentSecurity.NodeProvider.VSNodes.EnumVsRules(...)error  VSE CPlugin::Init: failed to determine plugin rule status[...] for [Cyren Engine]error  VSE ReloadPluginData: plugin failed to initialize plugin from configuration[...]

 	* PDF: I can confirm it’s a “Recorded Steps” document (title “Aufgezeichnete Schritte”), but it’s compressed PDF content and not text-extractable here. If you want, paste its textual summary (or send the original PSR .mht) and I’ll integrate it.

 Here's the opinion of AI whether I should reopen that github: Short answer: it’s not the same problem.  

 Net: The GH-14663 “FailedMails for all pickup” symptoms are not present here; 

	* Different symptom 

	* GH#14663: All pickup emails go to EmailSecurity\FailedMails (mail flow broken). 

 	* 60218313: Mail flow is OK; the web UI crashes with a NullReference when building the Virus Scan Engines tree.

	* Different failing component 

	* GH#14663 root causes: MTA init bug and EE exploit engine loader (eecore.dll deps). 

 	* 60218313: ContentSecurity.NodeProvider.VSNodes.EnumVsRules(...) throws NullReference (UI node provider), no EE/MTA failures observed.

Recommendation: 

 	* Don’t reopen #14663 (it was closed for a different root cause). Open a new issue titled “UI NullReference in VSNodes.EnumVsRules (Virus Scan Engines) – ticket 60218313”, link to #14663 as context only.
 	* If you still prefer to use #14663, add a comment clarifying it’s a separate UI-only defect (no FailedMails, mail flow OK) and request a new issue be split off.

 Answer to your questions: 

 	* Yes—based on logs, the “FailedMails”/EECore issues from GH#14663 do not persist here; engines aren’t failing to load, and mail flow is OK.
 	* The PSR (MHT) corroborates a UI navigation/repro, not a pipeline failure. The persisting issue is the UI NullReference in VSNodes.EnumVsRules.

Kayako - ticket id 60218313 // Aditi Garg commented publicly: Dear Carlos,

Thank you for detailed information. 
Our Engineering team has identified the issue, where a specific file — exploitdb.mdb — may not be copied into its expected directory:
C:\Program Files (x86)\GFI\MailEssentials\EmailSecurity\Engines\eed\

Temporary Workaround:
To resolve this issue, please follow these steps:

	* Manually copy the exploitdb.mdb [https://drive.google.com/file/d/1SC1EuU_-6aZ9xqzUAqJZyDjb5vIgvwV5/view] file into the directory listed above.
	* Restart the GFI MailEssentials Attendant service.

Permanent Resolution:
Our team is currently working on a fix. A more robust installation and staging logic for this file will be included in the upcoming MailEssentials 22.3 release.
We apologize for any inconvenience this may cause and appreciate your patience as we work toward a permanent resolution. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you need assistance implementing the workaround or have any further questions.

Best regards,
Aditi Garg
GFI - MailEssentials Support Team

Kayako - ticket id 60218313 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Support,

Thank you for your update and for confirming that all suggested troubleshooting steps have already been performed. I have reviewed the detailed information provided and the diagnostics from your screenshots. Below is a comprehensive overview and targeted guidance based on the persistent issues with the Virus Scanning Engine (VSE) “Failed [VSE]” error and the "Object reference not set to an instance of an object" message in the Email Security/Content Filtering section.

Current Situation Based on Your Diagnostics:

 	* GFI MailEssentials version: 22.2 (build 20250813) is installed, and the affected area is the Information Store Protection (VSAPI) under Email Security.
 	* VSE failure: Multiple AV engines (BitDefender, Avira, Sophos) are licensed and listed, but scan results return “Fehlgeschlagen [VSE]” (Failed [VSE]) for internal emails, which indicates a failure at the scanning engine level.
 	* UI configuration error: When accessing the Information Store Protection settings, the error “Der Objektverweis wurde nicht auf eine Objektinstanz festgelegt” ("Object reference not set to an instance of an object") is consistently encountered, blocking access to critical configuration pages.

Relevant Findings from Knowledge Base and Analysis:

 	* Article references confirm that “Failed [VSE]” errors result when an antivirus engine within MailEssentials fails to load, fails to update, or develops corruption—as documented in this article [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117808].
 	* The persistent “Object reference not set...” error is generally attributed to a corrupted configuration, missing or problematic dependencies (often SQL Server Compact), or deeper corruption in the information store engine module. This is supported by this guidance article [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/116264] and this update-related article [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117797].
 	* When neither a repair nor a reinstallation resolves such errors, and all isolation/troubleshooting steps (AV exclusions, folder checks, fresh installs, component reinstalls) fail, it indicates an issue potentially outside the scope of standard troubleshooting—frequently only resolved by upgrading to the latest product build (where bugfixes are implemented) or disabling the problematic scan engine as a long-term workaround.

Recommended Next Steps Based on All Diagnostic Info and Documentation:

 	* If you are not on the absolute latest build of GFI MailEssentials, it is strongly recommended to upgrade to the newest available version. Many unresolved or persistent VSE and configuration errors are addressed in subsequent product updates. For further instructions, refer to Mailflow stops with Failed VSE error on ME 20.3 [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117660]. 

	* If updating is not possible (license, OS, or environment limitations), and the error persists after all standard steps: 

 	* Keep all but the essential Virus Scanning Engines enabled and permanently disable the problematic engine(s) if identified, as referenced in Bitdefender fails to initialise, emails are failing with Failed VSE [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117679].
 	* If the configuration UI prevents you from disabling the engines or making changes, and repair/reinstall does not restore UI functionality, this confirms a deeper corruption which, per the knowledge base, requires a product upgrade or a new installation for resolution.

 	* Additional Review: Review the Windows Event Viewer for related application or system errors at the time the issues occur. This might provide more detail if a particular DLL or dependency is failing to load—information that is useful for deciding if further operating system troubleshooting is required. 

References:

 	* Virus Scanning Engine Generates 'Scan Result: Failed [VSE]' Error [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117808]
 	* Mailflow stops with Failed VSE error on ME 20.3 [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117660]
 	* AntiVirus Updates Fail with Message: 'Object reference not set to an instance of an object' [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117797]
 	* Bitdefender fails to initialise, emails are failing with Failed VSE [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117679]

If after an upgrade the issues persist, or the configuration UI remains inaccessible despite a completely fresh reinstall with the latest build, this would confirm an environmental factor or unsupported scenario. At that stage, re-evaluating the operating environment or performing a full server backup and clean install may be required to fully restore functionality.

Please let us know if you have upgraded to the most recent version and whether this approach brings the Email Security/Content Filtering functionality back online.

Sincerely,
Atlas
GFI - MailEssentials Support Team.

Kayako - ticket id 60218313 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear Support,

Thank you for providing detailed feedback, screenshots, and a summary of the ongoing issue with GFI MailEssentials after your recent reinstall on your Exchange server. Based on your report and the attached images, there are two main symptoms: (1) Virus Scanning Engine (VSE) failures resulting in "Scan Result: Failed [VSE]" for emails, and (2) an “unexpected error” in the configuration interface, which prevents you from accessing email security/content filtering functions with error details such as "Der Objektverweis wurde nicht auf eine Objektinstanz festgelegt" ("Object reference not set to an instance of an object").

1. Addressing the "Failed [VSE]" and AV Engine Errors:

This issue usually indicates that one of the antivirus engines failed to load properly or is unable to update. Common causes include permission issues on temp folders, AV conflicts, or update failures. The following steps are recommended:

 	* Ensure that temporary folders (%temp% and C:\Windows\Temp) are not full and are accessible. You may want to clear them.
 	* Make sure no other antivirus product is interfering with the folders: 
C:\Program Files (x86)\GFI 
C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\GFI 
 	* Add firewall exclusions for update servers such as update.gfi.com, meupdate.gfi.com, and the other domains listed in the following article: 
Virus Scanning Engine Generates 'Scan Result: Failed [VSE]' Error [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117808] 
 	* If the problem persists, temporarily disable the Virus Scanning Engines one by one in the MailEssentials configuration UI (under Email Security > Virus Scanning Engines) to identify which engine is causing the failure. Once identified, you can leave the problematic engine disabled as a short-term workaround while the root cause is further investigated.

For reference and detailed steps, please see: Virus Scanning Engine Generates 'Scan Result: Failed [VSE]' Error [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117808]

2. Resolving 'Unexpected Error' when Accessing Email Security/Content Filtering:

The error message and stack trace ("Object reference not set to an instance of an object") strongly resemble a known issue that can be caused by a missing or corrupted SQL Server Compact component or by engine/configuration corruption.

Workaround:

 	* Make sure SQL Server Compact 3.5 is installed and correctly registered. If missing or corrupted, you can download and reinstall it from the official Microsoft site as described here:
 	* Error: 'An unexpected error occurred in GFI MailEssentials configuration' [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/116264]
 	* After installation, restart the GFI MailEssentials services and attempt to access the relevant configuration page again.
 	* If the product version is outdated or issues persist, upgrading to the latest version of MailEssentials is strongly recommended, as many critical issues are resolved in newer versions.

Summary of Steps:

 	* Clear and check permissions on the server's temp folders.
 	* Set antivirus and firewall exclusions for GFI folders and update servers.
 	* Identify and temporarily disable any problematic Virus Scanning Engine.
 	* Verify and reinstall SQL Server Compact 3.5 if necessary.
 	* Upgrade GFI MailEssentials to the latest available build if the problem persists.

References for your convenience:

 	* Scan Result: Failed [VSE] Error – Troubleshooting Steps [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/117808]
 	* Unexpected Error in GFI MailEssentials configuration [https://support.mailessentials.gfi.com/article/116264]

If you still encounter issues after these steps, please note any specific AV engine causing the problem or any changes in the error messages, as this may help narrow down the root cause.

Sincerely,
Atlas
GFI - MailEssentials Support Team.

- Im GFI MailEssentials Configurationsbereich tritt ein unerwarteter Fehler auf, der ein Laden der aktuellen Seite verhindert.
- Die Fehlermeldung lautet: „Der Objektverweis wurde nicht auf eine Objektinstanz festgelegt.“
- Die Stack-Trace zeigt, dass das Problem im Modul „ContentSecurity.Configuration.IsOptions.GetCurrentState“ und „ContentSecurity.Configuration.IsOptions.propSheetView_LoadingSettings“ auftritt, insbesondere beim Laden der Seite („Page_Load“).
- Die Fehler treten auf, wenn der Bereich „Informationsspeicherschutz“ im Menü „E-Mail-Sicherheit“ geöffnet wird.
- Der Fehler verhindert, dass die Email-Sicherheits- und Inhaltsfilterfunktionen konfiguriert werden können.
- Empfehlungstexte im Screenshot raten dazu, den Dienststatus und den E-Mail-Fluss zu überprüfen sowie Events im Windows Event Viewer zu kontrollieren.

Kayako - ticket id 60218313 // ADN Support commented privately: Mr Dederding reports that none of the knowledge base entries (KBs) provided by ADN solved the problem or applied to his case.
After uninstalling GFI MailEssentials and restarting the Exchange server, Exchange initially failed to start.
After reinstalling, Exchange and mail flow via GFI are working again, but an error remains that prevents the email security and content filtering function from working.
